I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
equity investment of up to the lesser of (a) the equivalent in Singapore dollars of $4.0 million 
and (b) 40% of the issued capital of a limited company, provisionally ATRIUM PDFCO Limited 
(ATRIUM  PDFCO  [Asia  Training  and  Research  Initiative  on  Urban  Management  Project 
Development Facility Company Limited]), to be incorporated in Singapore. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.    
 
II.  BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 
A.  ADB’s Water and Wastewater Operations 
1.  Water Financing Program 
2.  Consistent with ADB’s water policy,1 the principal objectives of ADB assistance in the 
water and wastewater sectors are to (i) provide safe drinking water and sanitation facilities to 
improve the health and productivity of large urban populations, (ii) address environmental issues 
in  the  water  sector,  (iii)  improve  financial  management  to  generate  internal  resources  for 
investment and ensure sustainable operations and maintenance, and (iv) enhance institutional 
capacity to operate and maintain urban systems effectively. 
 
3.  ADB’s Water for All policy was reviewed in 2006 by an independent review panel which 
made five  main recommendations for ADB to improve implementation of the policy.2 The 
recommendations, which were accepted by ADB’s Board of Directors, are as follows. 
 
(i)  Increase  commitments  and  develop  capacity.  ADB  should  double  its  water 
investments, together with capacity development and a major public-awareness 
campaign. 
(ii)  Develop  long-term  partnerships  with  clients  and  stakeholders  in  developing 
member countries (DMCs) and among donors. ADB should focus on building 
broad-based support for the water policy’s principles through regional and in-
country  programs,  which  should  have  a  long-term  focus  rather  than  being 
project-centered.  
(iii)  Focus the implementation of integrated water resources management (IWRM) on 
stakeholder needs and ownership. ADB should provide continued support to 
promoting IWRM through training, planning, and implementation.  
(iv)  Promote "business unusual" through innovations to increase access, affordability, 
efficiency,  and  cost  effectiveness.  ADB  should  implement  the  new  financial 
instruments of its Innovation and Efficiency Initiative3, and clarify its policy on 
subsidies. ADB should also work harder at expediting service delivery to the poor 
to  help  countries  meet  the  Millennium  Development  Goal  (MDG)  targets. 
Alternative  investment  modalities  with  shorter  gestation  periods  should  be 
explored.  
(v)  Improve ADB processes to ensure effective policy implementation. ADB should 
streamline  its  internal  processes  to  integrate  the  water  policy  into  project 
operations in DMCs. 
                                                 
1   ADB. 2001. Water for All. Manila. 
2   ADB. 2006. Comprehensive Review of ADB’s Water Policy Implementation, Final Report and Recommendation.  
    Manila. Available: http://www.adb.org/Water/Policy/panel-report.asp 
3   ADB. 2005. Innovation Efficiency Initiative. Manila.

2   
4.  In March 2006, in response to the panel’s recommendations and the Asia and Pacific 
region’s  burgeoning  need  for  water  investment,  reform,  and  capacity  development,  ADB 
management announced the Water Financing Program (WFP) 2006–20104 that seeks to deliver 
water investments of $12 billion through ADB’s own resources over the period 2006–2010 
(Appendix 2). On an annual basis, the WFP seeks to double investments from $1.2 billion in 
1999 (before adoption of the water policy) to over $2 billion. Water lending was projected to 
reach 25% of overall ADB lending on a 3-year moving average. In December 2006, ADB’s 
Board of Directors approved the establishment of the Water Financing Partnership Facility to 
support WFP implementation. Water investments were also prioritized in ADB’s Medium-Term 
Strategy II, 2006-2008. 5
 
5.  The WFP has three main areas of investment: rural, urban, and basin water. 
 
(i)  Rural water services. Rural water supply and sanitation, irrigation, and drainage 
services to improve health and livelihoods.  
(ii)  Urban  water  services.  Urban  water  supply,  sanitation  and  wastewater 
management,  and  environmental  improvement  services  to  sustain  economic 
development.  
(iii)  Basin  water  management.  Infrastructure  and  management  for  (a) 
multifunctional water regulation and hydropower facilities developed in a river 
basin context; (b) flood management; (c) the conservation and improvement of 
watersheds, wetlands, and ecosystems; and (d) improved water governance. 
 
6.  The WFP also aims to offer a single-window approach for processing investments that 
have  both  public  and  private  financing,  especially  in  urban  water  services.  Using  its  new 
financing modalities developed by the Innovation and Efficiency Initiative, a diverse range of 
financing and knowledge products will be made available for rural, urban, and basin water 
investments. 
 
2.  Country Strategy and Private Sector Operations in the People’s Republic of 
China 
7.  The ADB country strategy for the PRC6 is based on five development objectives: (i) 
promoting equitable and inclusive growth, (ii) making markets work better, (iii) improving the 
environment,  (iv)  promoting  regional  cooperation,  and  (v)  private  sector  development  and 
operations. This is consistent with priorities highlighted in the ADB Medium-Term Strategy II 
(2006–2008), including (i) catalyzing investment to improve the investment climate and expand 
private  sector  operations,  (ii)  strengthening  inclusiveness  through  increasing  investment  to 
support rural development and social development interventions, and (iii) promoting regional 
cooperation  and  integration.  In  the  PRC,  ADB  is  enhancing  its  focus  on  rebalancing 
development between rural and urban areas, and between coastal and inland regions. There is 
more emphasis on infrastructure projects in rural areas and the less-developed central and 
western regions. The Government and ADB are also working together to promote improvements 
to the urban environment. 
 
8.  The PRC has been steadily transforming to a market economy, which has become the 
basis and driving force for economic growth and job creation. In addition to policy advice to the 
                                                 
4  ADB. 2006. Water Financing Program 2006-2010. Manila. Available: http://www.adb.org/Water/WFP/default.asp  
5  ADB. 2006. Medium-Term Strategy II 2006–2008. Manila. 
6  ADB. 2006. Country Strategy and Program Update (2007–2008): People’s Republic of China. Manila.

3
Government  on  private  sector  development,  ADB  also  provides  project-based  financial 
assistance. ADB’s private sector operations in the PRC have focused on the infrastructure and 
energy sectors, the financial sector, and environmental improvements. In the infrastructure and 
energy sectors, ADB prioritizes pioneering projects with innovative contractual and financial 
structuring to (i) encourage private sector participation, (ii) enhance management expertise, and 
(iii) improve corporate governance. The proposed project goes towards meeting these criteria of 
being a pioneering project that has not been previously tried by ADB and that will accelerate 
private sector participation in the water and sanitation sector in the PRC. 
 
9.  ADB has played a particularly significant role in promoting private sector involvement in 
the PRC’s water sector. In 1996, ADB technical assistance promoted private sector involvement 
on a build-operate-transfer (BOT) basis for water supply projects.7 This was followed by further 
technical assistance to help the Government prepare a pilot BOT project8 which resulted in the 
successful preparation and implementation of the Chengdu Water Supply Project,9 which is now 
in commercial operation. 
 
3.  Experience and Strategy in Water and Wastewater Sectors in the People’s 
Republic of China 
10.  The PRC is one of the main target countries of the WFP. The other target countries are 
India, Indonesia, Pakistan, and Viet Nam, which together with the PRC account for about 80% 
of  the  current  water  investments.  ADB  works  with  the  PRC  government  to  improve  living 
standards  and  economic  productivity,  reduce  environmental  degradation,  and  promote 
sustainable development. ADB is financing urban wastewater, sewage treatment, water supply, 
and water resource management projects in line with its strategy to support environmental 
improvement in the PRC. To maximize the development impact, especially among the urban 
poor, ADB's involvement has been targeted at densely populated urban areas. Since 1992, 
ADB  has  provided  more  than  20  loans  totaling  $2.5  billion  to  the  PRC  for  municipal 
infrastructure and environmental improvement projects. ADB also has provided nearly $45 
million for more than 70 technical assistance studies to prepare these projects and to review 
and  study  key  issues  in  municipal  transport,  water  resources,  water  supply,  wastewater 
treatment, and pollution control. It is anticipated that ADB's public sector operations in the PRC 
will support six or seven urban wastewater management projects in 2006–2008. 
 
B.  Water and Wastewater Sectors in the People’s Republic of China  
11.  Reducing the pollution of rivers and lakes and improving the supply of clean drinking 
water  is  part  of  any  pro-poor  development  strategy.  Poor  people  are  most  vulnerable  to 
environment-induced diseases and are least capable of paying for adequate medical attention 
for digestive tract ailments associated with drinking polluted water. The pollution of rivers and 
lakes  reduces  already  scarce  drinking  water  sources.  Bottled  water  is  a  very  expensive 
alternative to potable tap water. The financial burden of buying bottled water falls most heavily 
on the poor and can account for a disproportionately high portion of their limited income. Much 
remains to be done to reduce the adverse impact of water pollution on the poor and to end 
shortages of clean drinking water. 
                                                 
7  ADB. 1995. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for a Seminar on BOT in Water Supply Sector. 
Manila. 
8  ADB. 1997. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for BOT Chengdu Water Supply. Manila. 
9  ADB. 1999. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan to the 
People’s Republic of China for the Chengdu Generale des Eaux-Marubeni Waterworks Project. Manila. Approved 
for a direct loan of $26.5 million and a loan under the complementary financing scheme of $21.5 million.

4   
 
12.  In the PRC, only about 40% of urban wastewater is treated and the rest is discharged 
untreated into rivers, lakes, and seas. More than 40% of the water in the seven major river 
basins  does  not  meet  the  grade  III10  national  quality  standard.  Major  lakes  have  serious 
eutrophication problems. 
 
13.  The pollution of rivers and lakes puts further pressure on already scarce water sources. 
Water resources and availability in the PRC vary significantly across regions and during the 
year, and water scarcity is one of the biggest challenges facing the country. There are serious 
water shortages in northern PRC. Per capita water availability ranges from 360 cubic meters 
(m3) to 750 m3, both of which are lower than the international definition of water scarcity of 1,000 
m3 per person. Although more than 90% of urban households in large cities have access to 
piped water, this figure obscures shortages in many cities, particularly those in the water-scarce 
northern provinces. 
 
14.  Increased urbanization has placed pressure on water supply and wastewater treatment 
and has had a negative impact on water quality. The urban population in the PRC was about 
577 million in 2006 and is forecast to exceed 800 million in 2015. Inadequate facilities for 
treating municipal wastewater have led to pollution of already scarce water sources. In 2006 the 
total drinking water coverage in the PRC was 83%, and sanitation coverage was 56%. More 
investment is needed to supply clean drinking water and to treat wastewater. The Government 
has set an ambitious development target of extending water supply coverage to 95%, and 
wastewater treatment coverage to 70%, by 2010. 11  
 
C.  Constraints and Opportunities for Project Preparation in the People’s Republic of 
China 
15.  A key element for success in accelerating the achievement of MDG target 10 is the 
development of bankable projects at the local level, which are able to (i) leverage government 
funds, and (ii) raise the balance of the investment capital required from other sources, including 
commercial and development banks, and the private sector. However, the traditional project 
development  activities  of  the  government,  including  through  the  project  preparatory  and 
advisory  technical  assistance  activities  supported  by  multilateral  and  bilateral  development 
partners, have not been efficient in terms of speed, flexibility, and project structuring to attract 
private sector investments. In addition, there are constraints in local government capacity, 
inclination, and mindset to independently develop such projects and efficiently implement them 
with  a  proper  understanding  of  debt  structuring.  Consequently,  there  are  many  good 
opportunities that cannot be taken up due to insufficient or unsatisfactory project preparation. In 
fact, investors with strong interest in the sector cannot actually identify suitable projects in a 
timely  manner  because  the  preliminary  project  information  is  insufficient,  or  its  quality  is 
unsatisfactory. These problems could threaten the momentum of the governments’ initiative. 
ATRIUM PDFCO responds to these issues with an innovative project development model, in 
which the needs of the Government, as well as the expectations of the private sector, are 
addressed in an appropriate manner through a private sector company structured as a program 
development facility. 
 
                                                 
10  Grade III represents the minimum standard of suitable water for treated potable water supply. 
11  Ministry of Construction Report presented at the 6th Minister’s Forum on Infrastructure Development for the Asia 
Pacific Region held in Beijing, 28–29 August 2007.

5
16.  There is tremendous potential for urban infrastructure finance, fuelled by the PRC’s 
strong and sustained economic growth as well as increasing urbanization. ATRIUM PDFCO will 
link infrastructure financiers to urban water supply, wastewater, and sanitation projects, and 
accelerate the economic development of the PRC. The company will contribute skills, resources, 
and experience to achieve high quality in the preparation of projects. ATRIUM PDFCO projects 
will be able to expand and diversify the investor base for local governments and municipalities, 
and lower their cost of capital, by meeting international standards of project preparation and 
structuring through the public tendering of projects.  
 
17.  The  responsibility  for  developing  water  infrastructure  falls  on  local  municipalities. 
However, funding for water infrastructure in municipalities is limited, mainly because (i) they are 
constrained by their limited financial budgets and overall infrastructure needs, (ii) they do not 
have  direct  access  to  multilateral  or  other  external  financing  sources,  and  (iii)  some 
municipalities may not be able to meet the Government’s counterpart funding requirements.  
 
18.  Private sector funding can help to overcome some of these limitations for both the water 
supply and wastewater treatment sectors. Private sector participation can also lead to more use 
of new technology and enhanced efficiency. The PRC’s private sector now accounts for more 
than 40% of gross domestic product (GDP), 60% of growth, and 75% of the new jobs being 
generated. Thus, the continued expansion of the private sector is also vital to the PRC’s 
prospects of alleviating the poverty of its remaining poor people.12   
 
D.  Government Policies and Plans 
19.  The  PRC  government  accords  priority  in  the  11th  Five-Year  Plan  (2006–2010)  to 
resolving water pollution and the scarcity of water, especially in urban areas, as the PRC 
government plans to develop small- and medium-sized cities to absorb surplus rural labor. 
Particular attention will be paid to investments in wastewater treatment plants and recycled 
water facilities, with an estimated investment of $44 billion during the 5-year period.13 The PRC 
government’s  strategy  in  the  water  sector  focuses  on  (i)  strengthening  water  resource 
management  and  developing  water  sources;  (ii) controlling  overextraction  of  groundwater 
resources; (iii) strengthening water pollution prevention and treatment, including construction of 
urban  water,  wastewater  treatment,  and  recycled  water  facilities;  (iv)  encouraging  water 
savings; and (v) introducing appropriate pricing for water supply and wastewater treatment to 
more  economic  levels.  To  complement  increased  investments  in  urban  water  supply  and 
wastewater treatment facilities, the PRC government will continue to encourage and support 
raising  water  and  wastewater  tariffs  to  commercial  levels,  which  will  improve  financial 
management for water and wastewater projects, and encourage private sector participation. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Project Description   
20.  The purpose of the investment is to facilitate the development of commercially viable 
projects through PPPs in the water and sanitation sector in the PRC. The ATRIUM PDFCO will 
be incorporated in Singapore with an initial share capital of $10 million. 
 
                                                 
12   ADB. 2007. PRC Country Assistance Program Evaluation. Manila. 
13  SDRC, MOC, and SEPA. 2007. 11th Five-Year Plan for Urban Wastewater Treatment and Recycled Water 
Facilities Development.

6   
21.  ATRIUM  PDFCO  will  be  an  advisory  services  company  providing  the  necessary 
resources and expertise to identify and develop projects from the concept stage until they are 
successfully tendered out as PPP projects. The services it will provide include feasibility studies, 
planning, design, financial structuring, and other tender preparation activities that will result in 
successful competitive tendering and the appointment of a successful bidder. The up-front effort 
of ATRIUM PDFCO will ensure that the projects are sustainable and commercially viable while 
facilitating a high-quality and cost-effective solution.  ATRIUM PDFCO will be paid a fee for its 
services.  
 
B.  Project Implementation Arrangements 
1.  Project Development and Operations  
22.  Based on local government requests and market demand, ATRIUM PDFCO will assist 
various local governments or municipalities to plan, design, structure, and tender PPP water 
and wastewater infrastructure projects. For each project, ATRIUM PDFCO will enter into a 
project development agreement with the respective local government or municipality, which will 
define issues such as exclusivity, working scope, and payment terms.  
 
23.  ATRIUM PDFCO envisages to assist in demonstrating local governments can attract 
private investments in the water and wastewater sector. It will be run as a profit-driven company 
in order to maintain its longer-term financial viability. ATRIUM PDFCO will be paid a fee by the 
successful  bidder  in  a  tender  of  any  targeted  project.  The  success  fee  will  provide  for  a 
complete recovery of ATRIUM PDFCO’s costs associated with such tender, plus a suitable 
margin for profit. No up-front payment will be made by the local government or municipality. It is 
anticipated that the local governments or municipalities will find ATRIUM  PDFCO to be  a 
convenient and efficient entity with which to develop financially viable water and wastewater 
infrastructure projects. 
 
24.  Under arrangements that will be made prior to the engagement of ATRIUM PDFCO by 
any municipality or other client, ADB will be permitted to provide funding for the projects. Such 
funding opportunities, if they materialize, will be subject to separate approval by the Board.  In 
the same way, each of the Singaporean shareholders will be permitted to participate in the 
tender  for  the  projects  but  will  not  be  given  any  priority.    ATRIUM  PDFCO’s  constitutive 
documents will preclude it from bidding  for, or financing, any of the ensuing projects.   
 
25.  ADB will also carefully protect its reputation risk by requiring as a condition for taking its 
shareholding in the company that it institutes appropriate operational procedures to address 
conflict  of  interest  of  the  Singapore  shareholders  of  ATRIUM  PDFCO  during  the  project 
screening and development stages.  Detailed conflict of interest procedures will be developed 
for the company.14 ADB will ensure that ATRIUM PDFCO will follow systems and procedures, 
broadly  consistent  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for  Procurement  and Guidelines  for  Selection  of 
Consultants, that will ensure objectivity and impartiality in the screening of projects and that the 
bidding process is carried out by the municipalities in a transparent manner. ADB will use its 
chairmanship  of  the  audit  committee  to  ensure  that  any  potential  conflicts  of  interest  are 
appropriately managed, monitored and reported to the board, and that any material related-
party transaction will be subject to approval by ATRIUM PDFCO’s board.  
 
                                                 
14 These will be wide-ranging and will, amongst other things, ensure that ATRIUM PDFCO will not, for example on 
behalf of the relevant authority, evaluate any tender in which any of the Singaporean shareholders is a bidder.

7
2.  Selection Criteria and Due Diligence 
26.  The project selection criteria to be used by ATRIUM PDFCO are expected to include an 
assessment of the necessity and urgency of the project, the strength of municipal government 
support, and tariff affordability. Qualification criteria will be drawn up to guide project selection. 
ATRIUM  PDFCO  will  thoroughly  evaluate  each  project,  focusing  on  financial  viability.  A 
significant portion of the evaluation work, which will include technical, legal, and financial due-
diligence before a proposal is submitted to the board of ATRIUM PDFCO for approval, will be 
outsourced to external consultants. During project preparation for tendering, projects will be 
reviewed periodically.  
 
C.  Environmental Aspects and Social Dimensions 
1.  Environmental and Social Aspects 
27.  The  investment  is  classified  as  environmental  category  C,  involuntary  resettlement 
category C and indigenous people category C. ATRIUM PDFCO will be only provide advisory 
services, and its activities will have no environmental or social impact.  
 
2.  Development Impacts 
28.  One of the key development impacts will be to expedite the delivery of urban water 
supply,  sanitation,  and  wastewater  services  in  the  PRC,  and  thereby  accelerate  the 
achievement of MDG target 10 in the PRC. Over one third of the country’s river systems are 
estimated to be polluted and more than 90% of the catchment areas around the cities are badly 
contaminated. About 50% of water resources do not conform to PRC drinking water standards. 
Investments in wastewater treatment will improve the environment and help arrest pollution of 
water sources, facilitating delivery of water that meets national standards and reducing threats 
to public health. Poor people tend to suffer the most economically from increased medical costs 
or loss of income as a result of waterborne diseases. Investments in wastewater will reduce 
these costs and contribute to improving the living conditions of the poor. 
 
29.  The Project will enhance capacity and ownership of local governments by supporting 
project preparation, and targeting transparency, fairness, and high standards of ethics in project 
tendering. Access to water has been a major problem in some municipalities, particularly in 
northern PRC. An increase in the water supply will also enable increased industrial output. 
Access to piped water supply increases productivity by eliminating time spent in fetching and 
queuing for water, and this time can then be spent on other productive activities. For the urban 
poor, access to safe drinking water reduces the risk of waterborne diseases, thereby improving 
health and productivity.  
 
30.  The project will promote private sector participation in urban water supply, sanitation, 
and wastewater management in the PRC, and thereby increase the amount of private capital 
invested in the urban water sector, which is crucial for the sustainable and efficient delivery of 
basic services as the resources available with government, especially at the local level are 
limited 
 
3.  Development Effectiveness 
a.  Project Performance

8   
31.  ATRIUM  PDFCO’s  operations  and  performance  will  be  assessed  against  specific 
operational and financial objectives. Effectiveness will be measured by (i) how successfully the 
Project attracts private sector capital, (ii) how it facilitates the development of municipal water 
and wastewater facility concessions, (iii) whether it helps in developing and expanding municipal 
water and wastewater infrastructure facilities, (iv) how much water is supplied and wastewater is 
treated by its facilitated investments, and (v) whether it improves the quality of urban life and 
public health. ATRIUM PDFCO will also be judged by its financial profitability, sustainability, and 
timely returns to investors. 
 
b.   Economic Sustainability 
 
32.  From an economic sustainability point of view, the ATRIUM PDFCO will be assessed on 
its ability to cost effectively (i) develop water infrastructure facilities; (ii) supply water to, and 
treat  wastewater  from,  consumers;  and  (iii)  contribute  to  environmental  improvements  and 
economic growth. Additional employment created as a result of implementation of facilitated 
investments will also be taken into account.  
 
  c.   Private Sector Development 
 
33.  ATRIUM PDFCO will be assessed on how it contributes to capacity development in the 
local  and  municipal  governments  to  manage  private  sector  participation  in  the  water  and 
wastewater sectors. The focus will be on its commercial and financial viability, and also on its 
catalytic effect on future private investments in the water and wastewater sectors, and on the 
broader economy.  
 
IV.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Proposed Equity Investment 
34.  The proposed ADB investment will be up to $4.0 million equivalent, to be disbursed in 
stages, for a stake of up to 40% of the equity capital of ATRIUM PDFCO. Capital will be 
contributed pro rata by the shareholders over a period of 5 years, based on the cash flow 
requirements of ATRIUM PDFCO. ADB’s shareholding in ATRIUM PDFCO will not exceed 40% 
at any time. 
 
B.  Justification 
35.  ADB’s  investment  in  ATRIUM  PDFCO  is  justified  on  the  basis  of  its  development 
impacts and significant demonstration effects. It is consistent with ADB’s water policy,15 and the 
WFP 2006-2010, and supports ADB’s operational strategies, as well as the need to boost 
private sector involvement in urban water supply, sanitation, and wastewater management in 
DMCs. These are more specifically discussed below. 
 
(i)  The project aims to contribute towards meeting MDG target 10 on water and 
sanitation in the PRC. The vast majority of the people in the world without safe 
drinking water and proper sanitation, 700 million (two thirds) of those without safe 
drinking water, and 2 billion (three quarters) of those without improved sanitation, 
live in the Asia and Pacific region. In the PRC, 268 million people need to be

9
provided  access  to  safe  drinking  water,  and  another  372  million  need  the 
provision of sanitation, in order to reach MDG target 10 by 2015.  
(ii)  In response to the huge unmet water needs of the Asia and Pacific region, and 
consistent  with  the  recommendations  of  various  international  initiatives16  to 
double water investments, ADB has made water a core business area under its 
Medium-Term Strategy II.17 ADB envisages doubling its water investments to 
over $2 billion annually.18 This will represent a significant contribution towards 
the achievement of the MDGs in the Asia and Pacific region.19   
(iii)  The investment is consistent with ADB's WFP 2006–2010 which comprises a 
strong  portfolio  of  loan  and  technical  assistance  projects.  It  focuses  on  the 
delivery of substantial investment, reform, and capacity development in three key 
areas:  urban  water  services,  rural  water  services,  and  water  resources 
management in river basins. 
(iv)  The project aims to boost private sector financing. Despite much international 
attention in past years to the importance of private sector financing, few public 
water utilities in the PRC have easy access to private capital. Of all global private 
funding for infrastructure, only 5% went to water supply and sanitation services, 
and since 2001, global private annual investment commitments have ranged 
between $1 billion and $2 billion a year, which is well below the peak level of the 
late 1990s.   
(v)  The investment in ATRIUM PDFCO is in line with ADB’s vision of ADB as a 
knowledge-based  institution.  In  the  major  DMCs,  and  the  PRC  in  particular, 
financial resource is no longer the bottleneck for the development of water sector. 
The major gaps between the demand for water infrastructure by municipalities 
and the supply of infrastructure investment and lending are due to insufficient or 
unsatisfactory  project  evaluation,  due  diligence,  tender  preparation,  risk 
allocation,  and  financial  structuring.  The  expertise  to  prepare  and  structure 
different types of projects is in high demand in these markets. The incorporation 
of ATRIUM PDFCO, with successful experience from both ADB and Singapore, 
will meet this demand in a commercially sustainable manner. The experience 
through ATRIUM PDFCO will also enrich ADB’s own knowledge on private sector 
operations the water and wastewater sector in PRC. 
(vi)  The Project reflects the infrastructure focus of ADB’s private sector operations in 
the region. In the infrastructure sector, ADB prioritizes pioneering projects with 
bankable  contractual  and  financial  structuring  to  encourage  private  sector 
participation,  enhance  management  expertise,  and  improve  corporate 
governance. The service to be provided by ATRIUM PDFCO may foster a large 
number  of  urban  water  supply,  sanitation,  and  wastewater  projects  to  be 
developed by the private sector, and ADB will therefore play a significant catalytic 
role by investing in ATRIUM PDFCO. 
                                                 
16 The World Panel for Financing Water Infrastructure in 2003 and the Gurria Task Force on Water Financing in 2006. 
The Gurria Task Force was chaired by Angel Gurria and followed up on the recommendations of the World Panel 
on Financing Water Infrastructure chaired by Michel Camdessus. It reported its findings to the 4th World Water 
Forum in March 2006 in Mexico City. ADB was a member of the panel and the task force. 
17 ADB. 2006. Medium-Term Strategy II 2006–2008. Manila. 
18 To meet MDG target 10 on water and sanitation in the Asia and Pacific region, the Asia Water Watch 2015 study 
by ADB, World Health Organization, United Nations Development Program, and United Nations Economic and 
Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific estimated that minimum annual investments of $8 billion are needed. 
19 MDG target 10 is to halve, by 2015, the proportion of people without sustainable access to safe drinking water and 
improved sanitation. Investments in water are also crucial in meeting other MDG targets, such as those relating to 
(i) the incidence of poverty, (ii) the proportion of the poor who suffer from hunger, (iii) reducing child and maternal 
mortality, (iv) the incidence of major diseases, and (v) environmental sustainability.

10   
(vii)  ATRIUM  PDFCO  will  itself  be  a  demonstration  project  on  the  merits  of 
infrastructure PPPs in Asia. Currently, although many local governments in the 
region are eager for private capital to be mobilized to provide essential services, 
they  have  not  been  very  successful  in  attracting  private  investors.  This  has 
resulted  in  the  nondelivery  of  services  such  as  water  and  sanitation  to  the 
poorest people. ATRIUM PDFCO can demonstrate that local governments can 
attract private investors with minimum financial commitment from the national 
governments to deliver better basic services to their people, particularly the poor. 
 
C.  Anticorruption and Combating Money Laundering and the Financing of Terrorism 
36.  The  Singaporean  investors  were  advised  of  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as 
amended to date) and policy relating to the Combating of Money Laundering and the Financing 
of Terrorism (2003). Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and 
transparency, ADB will require the Singaporean investors to institute, maintain, and comply with 
internal procedures and controls following international best practice standards for the purpose 
of  preventing  corruption  or  money  laundering  activities  or  the  financing  of  terrorism  and 
covenant with ADB to refrain from engaging in such activities. The investment documentation 
between ADB and the investors will further allow ADB to investigate any violation or potential 
violation of these undertakings.  
 
V.  ASSURANCES 
37.  Consistent  with  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian  Development  Bank,  the 
Government of Singapore and the Government of PRC will be requested to confirm that it has 
no objection to the proposed assistance to ATRIUM PDFCO. No funding will be disbursed until 
ADB receives such confirmation.  
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
38.  I am satisfied that the proposed equity investment would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and, recommend that the Board approve 
 
(i)  an  equity  investment  of  the  lesser  of  the  equivalent  in  Singapore  dollars  of 
$4,000,000 and 40% of the issued share capital of ATRIUM PDFCO Limited, on 
terms and conditions which are substantially in accordance with those set forth in 
this report and as may be reported to the Board; and  
 
(ii)  a waiver of (a) the single exposure limit; and (b) the requirement that ADB not be 
the largest single shareholder in an investee company.

Appendix 2  13
ADB’s WATER FINANCING PROGRAM 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) adopted its Water for All policy in January 2001. 
The  policy  promotes  a  national  focus  on  water  sector  reform,  to  foster  the  integrated 
management of water resources, and improve and expand the delivery of water services. ADB 
conducted  an  in-house  review  of  policy  implementation  in  2003,  and  commissioned  an 
independent panel for a comprehensive policy implementation review in 2005.1
 
2.  In  response  to  the  panel’s  recommendations  and  the  Asia  and  Pacific  region’s 
burgeoning need for water investment, reform, and capacity development, ADB management in 
March 2006 approved the launch of ADB’s Water Financing Program (WFP) 2006–2010 to 
double water investments and achieve specific targeted outcomes. 
 
3.  Water  investments  were  also  prioritized  in  ADB’s  Medium-Term  Strategy  II,  and  in 
December 2006, ADB’s Board of Directors approved the establishment of the Water Financing 
Partnership Facility (WFPF) to support WFP implementation. This followed the positive outcome 
of a review of WFPF’s predecessor, the Cooperation Fund for the Water Sector,2 at the end of 5 
years. 
 
A.  The Region’s Water Challenge 
4.  Rapid population growth, urbanization, and underperformance of existing water assets 
leave a large shortfall in meeting the region’s water needs. According to official statistics that 
tend to present an overly positive situation, more than 600 million people in the Asia and Pacific 
region are still without safe drinking water supplies and 1.8 billion have inadequate or no toilet 
facilities. The actual numbers may be much higher. Investments to meet these basic human 
needs, and to manage water resources and clean up water pollution, have fallen seriously 
behind demand.  
 
5.  The Asia Water Watch 20153 report published by ADB and partners in December 2005 
estimated that minimum annual investments of $8 billion are needed over the next decade to 
meet Millennium Development Goal (MDG) targets for safe drinking water and sanitation alone 
(this estimate is based on official coverage statistics). Additional investments are also needed 
for  irrigation  services,  river  basin  management,  flood  management  and  mitigation,  and 
wastewater management. 
 
6.  A panel led by Michel Camdessus in 2003 recommended a doubling of public and 
private water investments, and a taskforce led by Angel Gurria in 2006 pointed to a shortage of 
bankable water projects, mainly because of capacity constraints in local governments, water 
utilities,  and  river  basin  organizations.  The  Organization  for  Economic  Cooperation  and 
Development announced at the Stockholm World Water Week in August 2007 that it is about to 
publish research findings showing that infrastructure investment needs for water in the next 10 
years will be higher than for energy and transport investment.  
 
7.  Per capita water availability in the Asia and Pacific region over the past decades has 
shrunk to half of the world average, and seasonal fluctuations are much more severe than in 
                                                 
1  Available: http://www.adb.org/Water/Policy/review-panel.asp  
2  Five RETA projects were approved for a total of $18.1 million during the period 2001–2006.   
3  Asia Water Watch 2015. Available: http://www.adb.org/water/actions/REG/target-ten.asp

14    Appendix 2 
regions with a temperate climate. Moreover, seasonal changes in water availability are expected 
to increase sharply as a result of climate change. Yet the region has only limited ability to 
mitigate the impact of these fluctuations, as its water storage capacity is low at 10%, compared 
with 33% in North America. Meanwhile, water use in the region continues to increase at 2–3 
times the population growth rate, which is putting enormous strain on water delivery services 
and the sustainable management of water resources.  
 
8.  Investments in water are also crucial to meet the broader MDG targets of reducing 
poverty,  hunger,  child  and  maternal  mortality,  and  the  incidence  of  major  diseases,  and 
improving environmental sustainability. This has led some developing member countries in 
Southeast Asia to announce that they aim to accelerate investments to meet MDG target 10 on 
water and sanitation by 2010. 
 
9.  Asia Water Watch 2015 documented evidence that governments can generate benefits 
of  up  to  $6  for  every  $1  invested  in  safe  drinking  water  and  sanitation.  Conversely,  it  is 
becoming clear, although not yet sufficiently documented, that postponing much-needed water 
investments will significantly increase the costs of environmental clean-up and adversely impact 
gross domestic product (GDP) growth.  
 
B.  Independent Panel Review 
 
10.  The  independent  review  panel  (footnote  1)  made  the  following  five  main 
recommendations for ADB in 2006 to improve implementation of its Water for All policy: 
 
(i)  Increase commitments and develop capacity. ADB should double its water 
investments together with capacity development and a major public awareness 
campaign. 
 
(ii)  Develop long-term partnerships with clients and stakeholders in the DMCs 
and among donors. ADB should focus on building broad-based support for the 
water policy’s principles through regional and in-country programs, which should 
have a long-term focus rather than being project-centered.  
 
(iii)  Focus  the  implementation  of  integrated  water  resources  management 
(IWRM) on stakeholder needs and ownership. ADB should provide continued 
support to promoting IWRM through training, planning, and implementation. ADB 
should complete IWRM planning and implementation in five countries or five river 
basins by the end of 2006 to showcase this priority.  
 
(iv)  Promote  "business  unusual"  through  innovations  to  increase  access, 
affordability, efficiency, and cost effectiveness. ADB should implement the 
new financial instruments of its innovation and efficiency initiative, and clarify its 
policy on subsidies. ADB should also work harder at expediting service delivery 
to  the  poor  to  help  countries  meet  the  MDG  targets.  Alternative  investment 
modalities with shorter gestation periods should be explored.  
 
(v)  Improve processes to ensure effective policy implementation. ADB should 
streamline  its  internal  processes  to  integrate  the  water  policy  into  project 
operations in the DMCs. ADB should also improve its skills-mix by recruiting 
more specialists, by training staff, and by providing more incentives for improving 
water operations.

Appendix 2      15 
C.  ADB’s Position 
 
11.  By launching the WFP and making water a core investment area under the Medium-
Term Strategy II, ADB management gave a clear and positive direction. The WFP seeks to 
deliver water investments of $10 billion of ADB’s own resources over the period 2006–2010. On 
an  annual  basis,  the  WFP  seeks  to  double  investments  from  $1.2  billion  in  1999  (before 
adoption of the water policy) to over $2 billion. Water lending was projected to reach 25% of 
overall ADB lending on a 3-year moving average.  
 
12.  ADB will seek to mobilize and leverage cofinancing and investments from government 
clients (through counterpart financing), the private sector, and development partners to achieve 
the WFP’s targeted outcomes of : 
 
(i)  sustainable access to safe drinking water and improved sanitation for 200 million 
people, 
(ii)  more productive and efficient irrigation and drainage services affecting 40 million 
people, 
(iii)  reduced flood risk to 100 million people, 
(iv)  IWRM introduced in 25 river basins, and 
(v)  improved water governance.4 
 
13.  The WFP has three main areas of investment: rural, urban, and basin water. 
 
(i)  Rural  water  services.  Rural  water  supply  and  sanitation  and  irrigation  and 
drainage services to improve health and livelihoods.  
(ii)  Urban  water  services.  Urban  water  supply,  sanitation  and  wastewater 
management,  and  environmental  improvement  services  to  sustain  economic 
development.  
(iii)  Basin  water  management.  Infrastructure  and  management  for  (a) 
multifunctional water regulation and hydropower facilities developed in a river 
basin context; (b) flood management; (c) the conservation and improvement of 
watersheds, wetlands, and ecosystems; and (d) improved water governance. 
 
14.  The WFP also aims to offer a single-window approach for processing investments that 
have  both  public  and  private  financing,  especially  in  urban  water  services.  Using  its  new 
financing modalities developed by the Innovation and Efficiency Initiative, a diverse range of 
financing and knowledge products will be made available for rural, urban, and basin water 
investments. 
 
15.  The WFP’s main target countries are India, Indonesia, Pakistan, the People’s Republic 
of China, and Viet Nam, which together account for about 80% of the current group of water 
investments. 
 
                                                 
4  Targeted outcomes for improving water governance are being developed.
